title: Tidy Tuesday Week 10/06
description: Tidy Tuesday for the thrid week
contents:
library(tidyverse)     # for graphing and data cleaning
library(lubridate)     # for date manipulation
library(ggthemes)      # for even more plotting themes
library(ggplot2)
library(tidytext)
theme_set(theme_minimal()) # My favorite ggplot() theme :)





papers <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-09-28/papers.csv')





papers %>% 
  unnest_tokens(word,title) %>% 
  anti_join(stop_words) %>% 
  filter(year>2015 & !grepl("^[0-9]", word)) %>% 
  count(word,sort = TRUE) %>% 
  head(20) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = n,y = fct_reorder(word,n))) + 
  geom_col() + 
  labs(x = "Number of times appeared",
       y = "Words",
       title = "The most frequently used 20 words in titles of NBER papers from 2015-2021") + 
  theme_minimal()





The title often reveals the topic of the paper. As a economics major, I’m curious to find out what are the most popular topics in the field in recent 5 years. Therefore, I created the bar graph above, showing the most frequently used 20 words in titles of NBER papers. As the graph suggests, most of the parpers have evidence-based findings and the popular topics in recent years includes: market, policy study, health, labor, covid, and trade. One challenge I faced is to filter out words that are in numbers but in the end I decided to use grepl. If I have more time, I’ll try to break titles into shorter phrases instead of single words and see if I could draw more insights from that!

title: Tidy Tuesday Week 9/21
description: Tidy Tuesday for the second week
contents:
library(tidyverse)     # for graphing and data cleaning
library(lubridate)     # for date manipulation
library(ggthemes)      # for even more plotting themes
library(gganimate)
library(gifski)
theme_set(theme_minimal()) # My favorite ggplot() theme :)





billboard <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2021/2021-09-14/billboard.csv')





billboard %>% 
  mutate(week = as.Date(week_id,"%m/%d/%Y")) %>% 
  filter(week >= as.Date("2021-05-01") & week <= as.Date("2021-06-01")) %>% 
  arrange(week_position) %>% 
  group_by(week) %>% 
  slice(1:10) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = week_position, 
             y = song)) +
  geom_col() + 
  labs(title = "Ranking of Top 10 Songs in May of 2021", 
       subtitle = "Week: {frame_time}",
       x = "Ranking",
       y = "Song Name") + 
  transition_time(week)





The graph above shows how the ranking changed in May 2021 for songs that were top 10 for at least one week in May of 2021. I’m interested in creating this graph because I’m curious how the rankings for different songs change over time: will popular songs continue to be popular or will they just be replaced by other songs. From the graph, we can see that for the top 10 songs in May 2021, there are different trends: some remained unchanged over the month but some of the songs are popular in the beginning but end up anonymous. Along the process, I’ve struggled with selecting the top 10 songs of each week but in the end, used “slice” to solve the problem.
